721604f-b.title: Manhattan: Marble Hill Avenue - Fort Charles Place
721604f-b.text:
Marble Hill Ave., east side, at the head of Fort Charles Place, showing
a general view northward across an excavation for a new apartment house.
Shown on Broadway are the elevated tracks of the west side I.R.T. subway.
All structures seen across same are in the Bronx; those on the left being
in Marble Hill, Manhattan. On the extreme left is a 27-story frame
house (No. 86 Marble Hill Ave.) while north of same and fronting on
the same avenue is St. Stephens M.E. Church. This is a set of three views;
No. 2 showing a close-up of the new apartment site and No. three, the
same area in an eastward direction from Broadway and West 230th Street,
in the Bronx.
721604f-b.folder: Marble Hill Avenue & Fort Charles Place, Manhattan, NY

719788f-a.title: Manhattan: Fort Charles Place - Marble Hill Avenue
719788f-a.text:
Fort Charles Place, north to Marble Hill Avenue, showing
the repaving of this residential street by the Works Pro-
gress Administration. Beyond the trucks appear apartments
on the far side of Marble Hill Avenue.
May 3, 1937
1-2-3
W. P. A., photo
Five Boroughs Project
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE

721607f-a.title: Manhattan: Marble Hill Avenue - 227th Street (West)
721607f-a.text:
Marble Hill Ave., (formerly Kingsbridge Ave., running from right
center, to center background), north from and including West 227th Street
(left, formerly Wicker Place), showing King's Bridge, thrown across
Spuyten Duyvil Creek (no longer in existence) and connecting Manhattan
with the Bronx. On the right slightly hidden by tree, is No. 96, a 2A-
story frame house, obstructing from view (partially) St. Stephen's
Church (M.E.), at the S.E. corner of 228th Street. Acrosh the Crhek are
visible the hills in the Bronx, as seen from the former site of Fort
Prince Charles (hill, left foreground, now 1937 occupied by a 6-story
apartment house, the Fort Prince Charles Court). For further data see
view 1.
March 28, 1906.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
721607f-a.folder: Marble Hill Avenue & 227th Street (West), Manhattan, NY

721606f-a.title: Manhattan: Marble Hill Avenue - 227th Street
721606f-a.text:
Marble Hill Ave. (formerly Kingsbridge Ave., running from right fore,
to center background), north from and including West 227th Street (formerly
Wicker Place), showing King's Bridge, thrown across Spuyten Duyvil Creek
(no longer in existence) and connecting Manhattan with the Bronx. The
3-story white frame house (right) bears No. 86; next to it, but slightly
separated is No. 96, a 2 -story frame house, partially obstructing from view
St. Stephen's (M.E.) Church, another frame structure, at the S.E. corner of
Marble Hill Ave. and West 228th Street (formerly Terrace View Ave.). The
22-story frame house, shown prominently, on the left, bears No. 91 Marble
Hill Ave., at the N.W. corner of West 227th Street, and is seen facing on
the latter Street. Between Marble Hill Ave. and the Creek is visible a
portion of West 228th Street, and across the Creek, in a northeasterly
direction, is the Borough of The Bronx, as seen from the former site of
Fort Prince Charles (hill, left foreground). The fort was built in 1776
during the Revolution and was named after Prince Charles William Ferdinand,
brother-in-law of King George III. It was constructed for the purpose of
controlling pasaage across King's Bridge, over Spuvten Duvvil Creek, which
in turn was built in 1693 by a royal grant given to Frederick Philipse,
by Eing William III, after whom it was named. In 1776 when the Hessian
Armv made decisive advances against the Colonials the fort was abandoned and
in Nevember, the Hessians who took possession of it, named it Fort Prince of
Brunswick, a brother-in-law of King George III of England. This area is
rich with the glorious traditions of the Colonials, who fought in these
environs many a battle under George Washington's command. A flag pole
now commemorates the site of the Fort.
March 28, 1906.
721606f-a.folder: Marble Hill Avenue & 227th Street, Manhattan, NY
